title: Villalta Score for Post-thrombotic Syndrome (PTS)
description: Diagnoses and stratifies severity of post-thrombotic syndrome in patients with history of deep venous thrombosis (DVT). The score combines patient-reported symptoms with physician-assessed clinical signs to provide standardized PTS evaluation.

parameters.name: pain
parameters.description: Patient-reported pain severity in the affected limb

parameters.name: cramps
parameters.description: Patient-reported cramping severity in the affected limb

parameters.name: heaviness
parameters.description: Patient-reported feeling of heaviness in the affected limb

parameters.name: paresthesia
parameters.description: Patient-reported paresthesia (numbness, tingling) severity in the affected limb

parameters.name: pruritus
parameters.description: Patient-reported itching severity in the affected limb

parameters.name: venous_ectasia
parameters.description: Physician-assessed venous ectasia (dilated superficial veins) severity

parameters.name: calf_compression_pain
parameters.description: Physician-assessed pain on calf compression severity

result.name: villalta_score
result.description: Villalta Score with PTS severity classification

ranges.interpretation: Villalta score indicates absence of post-thrombotic syndrome. Continue routine follow-up for DVT patients. Monitor for development of PTS symptoms over time, as PTS can develop months to years after initial DVT.

Villalta score indicates mild post-thrombotic syndrome. Initiate conservative management including compression therapy (20-30 mmHg), leg elevation, exercise, weight management, and patient education. Regular follow-up to monitor progression.

Villalta score indicates moderate post-thrombotic syndrome. Intensify conservative management with higher-grade compression stockings (30-40 mmHg), structured exercise programs, and weight management. Consider referral to vascular specialist for additional interventions.

Villalta score indicates severe post-thrombotic syndrome. Requires intensive management and specialist referral. Consider advanced therapies including intermittent pneumatic compression, venous interventions, and ulcer care if present. Significant impact on quality of life.

references: Villalta S, Bagatella P, Piccioli A, et al. Assessment of validity and reproducibility of a clinical scale for the post-thrombotic syndrome. Haemostasis. 1994;24(4):158a.

Kahn SR, Partsch H, Vedantham S, et al. Definition of post-thrombotic syndrome of the leg for use in clinical investigations: a recommendation for standardization. J Thromb Haemost. 2009;7(5):879-883.
Soosainathan A, Moore HM, Gohel MS, et al. Scoring systems for the post-thrombotic syndrome. J Vasc Surg. 2013;57(1):254-261.
formula:
Villalta Score = Sum of 5 symptoms (0-3 points each) + Sum of 6 clinical signs (0-3 points each)

Symptoms: Pain + Cramps + Heaviness + Paresthesia + Pruritus
Signs: Pretibial edema + Skin induration + Hyperpigmentation + Redness + Venous ectasia + Calf compression pain

Special rule: If venous ulcer present, score is automatically ≥15 (severe PTS)

Scoring: 0=Absent, 1=Mild, 2=Moderate, 3=Severe
Interpretation: 0-4=No PTS, 5-9=Mild PTS, 10-14=Moderate PTS, ≥15=Severe PTS
notes: The Villalta score is the most widely used and recommended tool for diagnosing and grading post-thrombotic syndrome severity.
Requires clinical examination of the affected limb by a trained healthcare provider.
Should be assessed at least 6 months after acute DVT when post-thrombotic changes have stabilized.
Presence of venous ulcer automatically classifies PTS as severe regardless of other symptom/sign scores.
Inter-observer reliability is good when performed by trained clinicians.
The scale combines patient-reported symptoms with objective clinical findings for comprehensive assessment.
